newsitem.title: DUBAI: Gulf firms set up more than 1,200 joint ventures.
newsitem.headline: Gulf firms set up more than 1,200 joint ventures.

text.p: Some 1,213 joint ventures between Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) companies and foreign firms had been set up by the end of 1996, Saudi Arabia's Ministry of Commerce said in a statement on Monday.
It said Saudi investments accounted for 12 billion riyals ($3.2 billion) of the joint ventures' total capital, which it put at 24.7 billion riyals. It did not say where the joint ventures operated.
The GCC, an economic and political alliance, is made up of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Oman and Qatar.
It said U.S. firms topped the list of joint venture partners with 187 firms.
A U.S. trade official in March said U.S. companies had invested $6.7 billion in Saudi Arabia by the end of 1996 accounting for about 46 percent of total foreign investments in the kingdom.
